This is the precise difference between arab and a'arab.
Short answer

عَرَبِي (ʿarabī / “Arab-ic”) – always an adjective for the language or style of the revelation.

ٱلْأَعْرَاب (al-aʿrāb / “the desert-dwellers, nomads”) – always a noun for a social group: Bedouin-type tribes living outside the towns around Yathrib/Medina.

That is the only contrast the Quran makes. It never calls the Prophet’s community “the Arabs”; it only calls the scripture “an Arabic Qur’an” and it calls the wandering tribes “the aʿrāb”.

1. Where the Qur’an says ʿarabī
Arabic phrase    Verse    Rashad Khalifa’s rendering
قُرۡءَٰنًا عَرَبِيًّا    12 : 2    “an Arabic Qur’an so that you may understand” 
Quran.com
بِلِسَانٍ عَرَبِيٍّ مُّبِينٍ    26 : 195    “in a clear Arabic tongue” 
Quran.com
لِسَانٌ عَرَبِيٌّ مُبِينٌ    16 : 103    “this is an eloquent Arabic tongue” 
Quran.com

All eleven occurrences of the root in this form (12 : 2; 13; 16 : 103; 20 : 113; 26 : 195; 39 : 28; 41 : 3, 44; 42 : 7; 43 : 3; 46 : 12) describe the medium of the message, never a people.

Morphology – faʿīl pattern, normal adjective; no hamza.

2. Where the Qur’an says al-aʿrāb
Arabic word    Verse    Rashad Khalifa’s rendering
ٱلْأَعْرَابُ أَشَدُّ كُفۡرًا وَنِفَاقًا    9 : 97    “The Nomads are the worst in disbelief and hypocrisy…” 
Quran.com
قَالَتِ ٱلْأَعْرَابُ آمَنَّا    49 : 14    “Some of the nomadic Arabs say, ‘We believe.’ …” 
Quran.com
ٱلْأَعْرَابَ ٱلَّذِينَ حَوْلَكُم    9 : 101    “the Nomads around you…” (context follows 9 : 97)

Ten occurrences (9 : 97-99, 101, 120; 33 : 20; 48 : 11, 16; 49 : 14) all talk about people who live outside the settled towns – sometimes hostile, sometimes sincere (9 : 99).

Morphology – hamza + afʿāl plural gives aʿrāb, traditionally glossed “Bedouins”. Classical lexicons contrast:

ʿarab = sedentary eloquent Arabs; aʿrāb = nomads of the desert.

3. What the distinction means
Language vs. lifestyle. The scripture is praised for its Arabic clarity; the aʿrāb are criticised or praised according to conduct, never language.

No racial label. The Qur’an does not use al-ʿarab for an ethnic bloc. Ethnic nationalism comes from later literature, not from the Quranic text.

Why the harsh tone? Desert tribes on Medina’s frontier controlled trade routes and could betray or support the believers. Verses 9 and 48 spell out that tension bluntly – some nomads were reliable allies, many were not. The wording is intentionally direct.

4. Bottom line for readers of the Final Testament
Word in Arabic    How Rashad Khalifa translates it    What it refers to
عَرَبِي/عَرَبِيًّا    “Arabic”    The language/tongue of the Qur’an
ٱلْأَعْرَاب    “the Nomads”    Desert-dwelling tribes, Bedouins

So whenever you read “Arabic” in the Final Testament you are seeing ʿarabī, and whenever you read “Nomads” you are seeing al-aʿrāb – two different words with two very different targets.
